description:
Gadus morhua, commonly known as the Atlantic cod, is a species of marine fish that belongs to the family Gadidae. It is a demersal fish, meaning it typically inhabits the bottom of the ocean.

The Atlantic cod is known for its distinct physical characteristics, including a robust, streamlined body, a large, gaping mouth, and three dorsal fins and two anal fins. The species typically ranges in color from greenish-brown to gray on the upper parts of its body, with a lighter, whitish belly.

Gadus morhua is a commercially important species, widely fished for its edible white flesh. It is found in the cold, temperate waters of the North Atlantic Ocean, with a distribution range that extends from the Barents Sea in the north to the Bay of Fundy in the south.

The Atlantic cod is an important part of marine ecosystems, serving as both a predator and prey species. It plays a vital role in the food web, contributing to the overall balance and diversity of the aquatic environment.
